text: FAANG companies are kafkaesque while startups are The Outsider. :laughing:

elements.text: FAANG companies are kafkaesque while startups are The Outsider.

text: What is the primary difference between product marketing and content marketing? In tech startups, with most of the marketing efforts revolving around content, do these two roles overlap a lot? Also, which path should you take to understand the product/domain more?

elements.text: What is the primary difference between product marketing and content marketing? In tech startups, with most of the marketing efforts revolving around content, do these two roles overlap a lot? Also, which path should you take to understand the product/domain more?

text: Hey guys and gals, would you recommend getting an MBA if you’re in content marketing? I’m thinking of getting one

elements.text: Hey guys and gals, would you recommend getting an MBA if you’re in content marketing? I’m thinking of getting one

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?

I suggest you figure out which jobs you're going to pursue and then work backward to see whether those jobs benefit from an MBA. For instance, if you shoot for more corporate roles, MBAs will tend to matter more. You can check LinkedIn profiles, for instance, and ask those kind of folks. In many settings, business thinking is valued, but you can get that in various ways, not necessarily via a degree.

FWIW, I don't even mention a degree on my LinkedIn profile and I get recruited by startups of all sizes, public companies, including FAANG. And that's even though I haven't job hunted in eight years+, since changing careers. That's because I have track record.

I did learn business thinking, but I did it via self-study, learning on the job and volunteering with a tech incubator run by a VC fund. For example, I got the curriculum from Harvard business school’s MBA program and asked my MBA coworkers which classes actually served them at work. Then I studied that material. One of my coworkers even gave me some of her textbooks and other materials from HBS. And with the tech incubator, I got exposure to a variety of companies and business models and helped them solve problems with an insider perspective. No MBA could've given me that much hands-on exposure across such breadth of businesses. I did that because I'd spent decades in my first career — daily journalism — and had no business exposure. I tried to figure out how to do compressed learning.

elements.text:
I suggest you figure out which jobs you're going to pursue and then work backward to see whether those jobs benefit from an MBA. For instance, if you shoot for more corporate roles, MBAs will tend to matter more. You can check LinkedIn profiles, for instance, and ask those kind of folks. In many settings, business thinking is valued, but you can get that in various ways, not necessarily via a degree.

FWIW, I don't even mention a degree on my LinkedIn profile and I get recruited by startups of all sizes, public companies, including FAANG. And that's even though I haven't job hunted in eight years+, since changing careers. That's because I have track record.

I did learn business thinking, but I did it via self-study, learning on the job and volunteering with a tech incubator run by a VC fund. For example, I got the curriculum from Harvard business school’s MBA program and asked my MBA coworkers which classes actually served them at work. Then I studied that material. One of my coworkers even gave me some of her textbooks and other materials from HBS. And with the tech incubator, I got exposure to a variety of companies and business models and helped them solve problems with an insider perspective. No MBA could've given me that much hands-on exposure across such breadth of businesses. I did that because I'd spent decades in my first career — daily journalism — and had no business exposure. I tried to figure out how to do compressed learning.

text:
BTW, I have only a journalism undergrad degree. Yet during my content career, I've held a couple of the top-paying jobs across the content landscape. (That's by comparing against Superpath’s compensation survey figures; by comparing against a salary survey I'm doing among many content folks; and because I've had access to compensation data purchased from Radford and such for the past seven years. Plus, when I led a large content team at NerdWallet for years, we crowd-sourced all the offers that folks on our team would share when they were being recruited; our team was continually heavily recruited. And I've spent the past eight+ years hiring 100+ content folks for my teams, so I’ve been seeing negotiated numbers for many candidates.)

I mention the above, because some people think degrees are the best path toward good jobs. I've not found that to be the case at all. And I've never even prioritized money — I love producing results, and money is a byproduct. Of course, it really helps to know how to negotiate. I've built those skills over years and I leverage everything I know about compensation across the landscape. While money isn't my highest priority, I try to never leave money on the table. That’s because you get more respect as an exec if you know how to negotiate, and you want to build credibility not only for you, but for the function and people you represent. (This is why I tell people to avoid working for managers who can't represent well; no matter how talented you are, you'll tend to get shorted by working for a weak manager. That's bc they're the ones responsible for getting your function resources and recognition.)

text: did someone say salary? here's some data that might be helpful. <https://superpath.co/blog/content-marketing-salary-report>

attachments.fallback: Your Content Career Headquarters: How Much Money Do Content Marketer's Make? (2022 Salary Report) — Your Content Career Headquarters
attachments.text: The average content marketing salary is $93,725. Check out our salary report for more detailed data on job titles, experience and pay discrepancies.
attachments.title: How Much Money Do Content Marketer's Make? (2022 Salary Report) — Your Content Career Headquarters

text: Oh, I should also mention: The value placed on education varies from country to country as well. In the U.S., more and more companies (including major ones) are less fixated on education as a criteria. They're increasingly open to candidates from a variety of backgrounds. YMMV in your country, if you live elsewhere.
